Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Mobile mmWaves: Addressing the Cellular Capacity Crisis with 60 GHz Picocells

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Smart phones and tablets enable consumers to enjoy rich audio and video content on the go, but the proliferation of such increasingly sophisticated mobile devices has created a capacity crisis for mobile operators. It is estimated that supporting rich media content for a rapidly increasing fraction of mobile users requires a 1000-fold increase in cellular network capacity, which current cellular bands simply cannot support. The research pursued under this grant explores an alternative, and potentially transformational, approach to cellular data, using unlicensed spectrum in the 60 GHz band, where the available bandwidth is orders of magnitude higher than those used in existing systems, at the level of multiple Gigabits per second throughput on the downlink to the mobile devices.

Base stations for the envisioned network will be deployed opportunistically (e.g., on lampposts and rooftops). Due to the small carrier wavelength, many antenna arrays with a very large number (e.g., 1000) of elements can be built into base stations which are no larger than a typical WiFi access point. Such antenna arrays can be used to direct pencil beams at mobile users, with peak data rates of multiples of Gigabits per second (order of magnitude higher than the highest WiFi data rates available today). However, the small carrier wavelength also implies that the radio waves are easily blocked by obstacles such as buildings, walls, and humans, including the body of the person carrying the mobile device. In order to handle such rapid changes in the propagation environment, novel techniques are developed for multiple base stations to coordinate, such that they can adapt their beams to maintain connectivity with a given mobile device, and can ensure that the data destined for the mobile follows it around. A novel asymmetric network architecture is employed, with low-bandwidth 60 GHz beaconing and multi-Gbps data on the downlink, and LTE feedback and lower-speed data on the uplink. The base stations employ compressive signal processing for rapid channel estimation and beam adaptation, based on the feedback from the mobiles. Distributed base station coordination mechanisms are developed for seamlessly switching base stations or paths. The architecture minimizes complexity and power consumption in the mobile device: the device's 60 GHz radio only needs to receive, and the device is oblivious of handoffs.

The mobile broadband capacity crisis is the greatest challenge facing cellular providers today, hence the success of this project can impact a multi-billion dollar industry. In order to maximize the potential for impact, the results and models will be widely disseminated to both industry and academia. The investigators plan significant efforts for recruitment and mentoring of female undergraduate and graduate students, organized around the concept of a caring community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the pervasive use of smartphones and tablets, and the popularity of image- and video-centric apps, mobile data traffic has exploded over the past decade, and continues to grow exponentially.  Mobile operators estimate that a 1000-fold increase in cellular network capacity, especially in densely populated urban cores, is required to keep up with this demand.  In this project, we have demonstrated that emerging wireless technology in the “millimeter wave” band is a promising approach for accomplishing this.  These bands are at frequencies that are an order of magnitude larger than those used in today’s cellular systems, and the available spectrum is orders of magnitude higher than the crowded bands used by today’s systems. The smaller carrier wavelength also implies that we can fit electronically steerable antenna arrays with a very large number of elements into a compact form factor, which enables synthesis of narrow pencil beams between transmitter and receiver.  This drastically reduces interference and increases network capacity.  A particular band of interest to us is the 60 GHz unlicensed band, where there is 14 GHz of available spectrum.

We propose a picocellular architecture that takes advantage of the unique features of mm wave, with base stations deployed opportunistically in urban areas (e.g., on lampposts) forming pencil beams towards mobile users.  There are two fundamental technical bottlenecks that we address in this project:

1) ``Objects look bigger at smaller wavelengths,'' so that the line of sight (LoS) path between base station and a mobile user can easily be blocked by obstacles. Thus, the feasible paths between base station and the mobile user can change rapidly, and when the LoS path is blocked, one must resort to alternative paths from reflecting surfaces or switch to neighboring base stations.

2) Digging fiber to every lamppost is infeasible, hence a large-scale picocellular deployment requires a wireless backhaul network connecting it to the Internet.  The backhaul links must be even faster than the access links from base station to mobile, since they will typically carry traffic from several picocells to the nearest gateway.

 

The outcomes of this project are techniques, demonstrated via analysis, simulations and field experiments, that relieve these bottlenecks.  We have also interacted and collaborated closely with industry to evangelize our ideas. Our key results are as follows:

(a) We first showed, and evangelized to the research community, the basic viability of 60 GHz mobile communication via field experiments, showing in both an urban and a campus setting that, at least for pedestrian mobility, currently available 60 GHz hardware can overcome blockage by beamsteering around it.

(b) We then developed an efficient and agile approach for tracking the available paths to highly mobile users (e.g., in vehicles).  The base stations send ``compressive’’ beacons using pseudorandomly adjusted beams, and employ feedback from the mobiles to estimate the available paths.  This work involved fundamental advances in signal processing algorithms and theory, and was demonstrated on an experimental testbed.  While high-mobility scenarios could not be demonstrated due to testbed limitations, our calculations show that vehicular mobility can be easily supported with low beacon overhead.

(c) We showed that mm wave networks can also be effectively used for wireless backhaul, and developed a framework for design of such networks, including a new approach for joint routing and resource allocation that ensures that each picocell gets enough data rate on the backhaul network.

 

An additional outcome that went beyond the originally proposed project was the development of techniques for ``reusing'' 60GHz networking radios for other mobile tasks. In particular, we showed promising results on imaging the environment by capturing 60GHz transmissions reflected by nearby objects, with interesting implications for future mobile imaging systems.

The impact of our research is amplified by our close interactions with industry partners, such as Facebook, Qualcomm, Samsung, Nokia, and Google, who supplemented this award with gift funding.  We note in particular our relationship with the Facebook Terragraph team, which donated mm wave network nodes that enabled many of our experiments.  Graduate students on this project helped disseminate our ideas, and gained hands-on experience, through summer internships in industry.

 

The project has also contributed to enhancing diversity via high-visibility research performed by women: one of the two investigators, and two of the five graduate students involved in this project are women.

 

Finally, the initial results obtained in the first two years of this project were leveraged to craft a larger vision for mm wave systems, which was funded by NSF as a large interdisciplinary project involving 6 investigators, with goals spanning hardware development, signal processing algorithms, and next generation network algorithms and protocols.
